meanings.definition: Mislead or give false information to (someone).
meanings.sent1: He tried to misplead his friend by telling a fake story.
meanings.sent2: The con artist would often misplead unsuspecting victims.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous child decided to misplead his teacher about the missing homework.
meanings.sent4: Her smooth words aimed to misplead the jury into believing her innocence.
meanings.sent5: The misleading advertisement was designed to misplead consumers into buying the product.

meanings.sent1: She accidentally misplead the instructions and ended up lost.
meanings.sent2: It's easy to misplead a situation when you don't have all the facts.
meanings.sent3: The confused tourist managed to misplead the local's directions and got even more lost.
meanings.sent4: His biased view caused him to misplead the intentions behind her actions.
meanings.sent5: The distorted mirror misplead her reflection, making her look taller than she was.

meanings.definition: Plead or argue incorrectly or falsely.
meanings.sent1: The lawyer accidentally misplead the defendant's case, leading to a guilty verdict.
meanings.sent2: She didn't mean to misplead, but her nervousness caused her to make false statements.
meanings.sent3: In a moment of panic, he managed to misplead his own innocence in the matter.
meanings.sent4: The politician's speech was filled with attempts to misplead the public into supporting him.
meanings.sent5: The student's attempt to misplead his way out of detention failed miserably.
